pros: Free meals, employee discounts, yearly bonuses, the longer you work the more bonuses you get after a year or more. customer service will improve, get to learn how to handle food preparation, "flexible working hours" and fun co-workers
cons: Stressful environment especially when it's busy. Once in a while stubborn and rude customers would come in and ask for unreasonable requests or claims. Despite having "flexible working hours", your manager would still bug you to come in work despite you saying that you would be busy and unavailable. New employees ( usually young ) would sometimes be put in a station straight away and would be forced to learn and remember on the spot while being under pressure and most of the time, busy. Some managers would not have the patience to wait for you to learn so they would be very expressive on how bad you are on the job and sometimes cheat their way through the system when doing admin stuff.

review_title: Great training great promotions great people
pros: It's a bottom up organization truly trying to get back to the basics of being a restaurant company driven by the customer
cons: All the internal politics, OPNAD - marketing structure and at least 1/3 of owners who have been around 10 years or less who think it's someone else's responsibility to make money for them ; 1/3 of owners who really believe they can save themselves into success ( run the business from an office and P&L) 1/3 who are getting so frustrated.

pros: Company is generous in spending money for team building and family events.
cons: Changes take a long time to happen, mainly because some departments are very protective of their turf, and insist that their inputs and blessings are mandatory. In addition, there are a lot of people who have been with the company forever, and they are too set in their ways.

pros: One Big Mac value meal's worth of employee meal per 8-hour shift
cons: High staff turnover + relatively low educational requirements => some 2nd Assistant Managers are no better than a "glorified" crew leader. Some of these are promoted by virtue of the fact that they have been in the system for so long (with no other employment options), coupled with the high staff turnover, such people are promoted. Network of internal relationships are deeply entrenched, resulting in far reaching ramifications.

pros: good basic pay with guaranteed tip sharing. good autonomy with several fringe benfits. friendly and jovial coworkers. fun place to work for part time
cons: management sometimes ask the part timers to leave early if the sales for the day is not good, but when it gets busy and sales are good there is no reward.

review_title: Why is McDonald's employee turnover so high? why do they offer so much $ for staff referrals?
pros: free employee meal (a Big Mac meal equivalent in value) ?
cons:
Management style is top-down in nature; hence, personal contribution is limited, not because an employee is dumb, but because employees are just expected to carry out instructions. It's like a factory
Many of the so-called "managers" are incompetent in managing staff. They are no more than over-glorified crews !  Such limitations in their abilities are reflected in only way that they know how to manage: SCOLD and BERATE employees, at times publicly in front of customers

pros: friendly people, good working culture, good working hours, work life balance, good benefit and allowance, fixed aws no matter what is the economic, good annual leave
cons: operation people always the priority where the rest of department is less empowered, people resist to change sometimes, people tend to overload at certain department with limited resource given, low increment

pros: Meal benefits and overall enjoyable place to work at. Flexible timings. Heard that pay has increased since the last time i worked there.
cons: Customers can be very rude. If you're manning the drinks section, it will be very stressful as you have to make cold and hot drinks, refill syrup, refill ice all at the same time. A little bit annoyed that managers and others expect one person to do everything at the same time immediately during peak hours.

pros:
High flexibility.
Managers are understanding regarding  my hectic schedules and are lenient about regular attendance.
cons:
Very Low wage.
High flexibility results in colleagues ditching their time slot last minute, so others have to be called in last minute to cover for them. Sometimes I need to stay back for few more hours though my shift has ended.

pros: It's a fun and warm office to work in.  Co-workers are nice and great leaders.  No hierarchy segregation.   1 policy applies across the board.  A company that doesn't just take care of employees but their family members as well.  Flexi working hours which is another plus
cons: Office software should be invested.

pros: Easier to get time off Easier to set your own hours Free/discounted food College help, 401k, and training Not too hard to move upwards but that's usually because a lot of people quit. Like any other place depends on the manager, co workers etc. but my store has some pretty good managers and co workers so it's a nice environment.
cons: My store does not pay competitively or I would argue fairly. Can be a bit physically straining The rate of rude and or verbally abusive customers is high enough that you run into at least 5 daily. For most part though they are not physical. Hard to find information to get access to some benefits they offer. Procedure changes alot. You have to learn on the go (not unassisted) which can be overwhelming for newbies No one wants to be a manager because we all see how they get steamrolled.

review_title: Good for money, Ok for teens. Wouldn't do it again.
pros: I earned ok pay during my time here You get very flexible hours managers are very flexible sometimes it's a good first job, nice to meet people, see customers and colleagues often A lot of people take this job whilst in studies (sixth form, college, uni etc) and you could also get an apprenticeship Food discounts, good amount of lunch each day, new friendships hours and quitting are very flexible.
cons: Managers think they're better than you! CUSTOMERS think they're better than you! Both parties above do not ask, just have a go at you via assumptions Think about the worst aspect this job could have and imagine doing it every day. Not liking something won't stop managers making you do it. You will be tired, sore etc at the end of each day.

pros: You get free food here
cons: On my very first day I was thrown to the wolves. With no experience in food service at all, I was told that I would be trained properly and not just thrown out there but that’s exactly what happened. As soon as I got there, I was put on the drive thru and put with a person that was very rude and berated me. After going over the screen for about 30 seconds, I was told to jump right in. Once I explained that I didn’t understand, I was berated and made to feel dumb. Then, I was asked by this person what my other job was since I didn’t have any food service experience and I told them, to which I was asked what I was doing working at McDonald’s and berated more. After having to basically pull teeth and get this person to actually somewhat train me, they spent about two more minutes to halfway explain to me again before they forcefully put me in charge of the drive thru and then proceeded to leave me there alone. I was like a deer in headlights and I didn’t know what to do. When this person did come back for a few seconds, they was on their phone on social media, not helping me at all when I asked for help. Then, proceeded to leave again and never come back. The drive thru got very backed up and I ended up walking out. I will never work here or probably anywhere else in food service ever again.

review_title: Managers don't train you properly the first week so they can justify low wages
job_title: Crew Member in San Antonio, TX
pros: Most people that work here as crew members are honest and good-natured.
cons: Managers lie and cheat employees out of earned pay. Managers don't train you properly the first week so they can justify low wages. They don't want you to grow and they don't want to promote you, because it costs them "too much money". I work in San Antonio's new Talley road establishment and many of the managers micromanage employees and put you down and put unnecessary pressure even during peak hours. Store is SEVERELY understaffed. On average days I do two stations simultaneously for 12 dollars even though they said they would pay 14/hr after training. So they never train me anymore even though they were supposed to do that the first week. Bad working conditions, managers will try to rush you at every opportunity and let other workers push you around. Managers never talk to their employees to check up on them individually. They just decide your schedule FOR you.

review_title: My Experience as a Kitchen Staff
pros: Training opportunities: McDonald's offers training programs for their employees to help them develop their skills and advance their careers. Discounts on food: As an employee of McDonald's, you may receive discounts on food, which can be a pro if you enjoy their menu.
cons: Physically demanding: Working in a fast-paced kitchen environment can be physically demanding, and employees may be required to stand for long periods of time, lift heavy objects, and perform repetitive tasks. Irregular shifts: McDonald's is often open late, which means that employees may be required to work late or overnight shifts. This can be a con for those who prefer regular daytime hours.

pros: Free lunch, most employees friendly. Flexible in terms of shifts. Fairly easy to become a shift manager
cons: Work was very physically and mentally draining, employees regularly given one 30 minute break and one 15 minute break later on, not nearly enough break time especially since a regular day was 9 hours. Also during break times four or more employees were forced to sit in break room the size of a rich man’s wardrobe, practically jostling for elbow space, if you’re an introverted person or simply want some quiet in your previous minutes of break time it’s very frustrating. I also got burned a couple times while on the fries station, one time the manager of the place actually burned me with a chip basket. Customers often impatient or unfriendly and at times your patience and self control will be tested.

pros: Next day pay helped, only starts after first pay check. Have to wait almost a month for first pay check if you come in the middle of a pay period.
cons: Always under staffed. Starting pay at 13 unless you are a opener or closer than it is 14.00. Going into management is very difficult. No training is provided. Was put on the grill the first day. Getting a 30 minute break was very hard because of the lack of workers. Worked for two months where I had to be the only person in kitchen for many hour or full shift working with drive thru open and the lobby open as well as mobile order like DoorDash.

pros: I have been employed with McDonald’s for about ten years now. I moved up the ladder pretty quickly. I was a salary manager within two weeks after I had my shift manager promotion. They treated me well when I worked there and took mental health seriously when needed. The staff for the most part were all kind hard working people who I befriended quite quickly.
cons: The hours are a little hard when you have three young kids at home. Also sometimes the shifts can be tiring when you’re on your feet all day.

review_title: Had both great times and bad times
pros: If you are in college, this is a great starter job. Since the pandemic, crew members would get free meals while on shift, discounts if not on shift, and much more. Closing shifts at a 24 hour store are fairly laid back as long as you have a good team. When the store is properly staffed, there is plenty of help and there is solid organization where everyone knows what to do and what station they are responsible for.
cons: A lot of drama happens and you'll see it if you stay there long enough. There can be managers who are completely unprofessional both in harassment/sexual misconduct and favoritism and upper management doesn't even notice what they are doing until it's gone on for months and they are finally disciplined or terminated. Your coworkers can definitely vary and be pretty bad at times with gossiping and rumor spreading, especially because many are in high school rather than college and above. A lot of people on certain shifts don't handle their positions properly and it causes slow downs in the drive through which fall back on the entire team.

review_title: Part time working as a student
pros: Most of the staff are friendly, free medium meal for big break and free small food item and drink for small break. Pay is decent and the hours are good. Employee card for discounted meals very handy as a student. Management never shout at you like some other jobs. Decent first job.
cons: Not allowed to receive tips, uniform is very strict, must clock out before ordering for break, some employees will be receive favouritism from managers. It is fast paced and sometimes stressful. Not a good place to work full time as it is hard to balance life with hectic scheduling.

pros: -Free Food (Usually, when working at any type of McDonalds, usually Management will award you with free food, or sometimes at 50% discount when ordering meals. -Leadership skills (Able to communicate and enhance your communication and leadership skills to a wide variety in your team) -Easy Job (In terms of doing your own duties, whether you may be cooking, doing the cashier, cleaning the restaurant, etc, it's a pretty easy job.)
cons: -Horrible Management (The Management to many McDonalds unfortunately has harsh environments. You are always being looked upon to make sure you are doing a good job.) -Boring Job (Unfortuantely, since this is a type of fast-food job, you don't get much to do, other than your own specific duties that were given to you. -Low Salary (Unforrtunately, you do not make as much money when working at a fast-food type of restaurant.)

pros: Job availability: McDonald's is a large employer, and they always have job openings available. This means that you are likely to find a job quickly, especially if you are a student or a first-time job seeker. Flexible schedules: McDonald's is often open 24/7, which means that there are a variety of shift options available. This can be helpful for people who have other commitments, such as school or family obligations. Opportunities for advancement: McDonald's is known for promoting from within, and there are opportunities for employees to move up the ranks and take on more responsibilities. Benefits: Depending on your location and position, McDonald's may offer benefits such as health insurance, paid time off, and 401k plans.
cons: Low pay: McDonald's is known for paying low wages, especially for entry-level positions. Difficult customers: As with any customer service job, you may encounter difficult customers at McDonald's. This can be stressful and challenging. Physical demands: Working in a fast-paced environment can be physically demanding, and you may be on your feet for long periods of time. Long hours: Depending on the location, McDonald's may be open for long hours, which can lead to long shifts for employees.

pros: It’s a good starter job for first time teens who are new to any workplace environment. McDonald’s is able to showcase and help practice your skills in terms of cooperation and time management amongst other elements.
cons: It isn’t a very good job on the long run, and some may not like working in a fast food place l.

pros: Worked amongst a tight knit crew in a cooperative, teamwork environment. As well as an emphasis on self reliance and independent working, hence creating responsibility in the pursuit of achieving defined goals and expectations. pros: Convenience: McDonald's is known for its quick and convenient service, making it a popular choice for people on-the-go or in a rush. Affordable: McDonald's offers a variety of affordable menu options, making it accessible to a wide range of customers. Consistency: McDonald's is known for its consistent menu and service across locations, ensuring customers know what to expect when they visit. Variety: McDonald's offers a variety of menu options, from burgers and fries to salads and breakfast items, making it easy for customers to find something they like. Accessibility: McDonald's has a large number of locations around the world, making it easy for customers to find a restaurant near them.
cons: Nutrition: Many of McDonald's menu items are high in calories, fat, and sodium, making them less healthy options compared to other dining choices. Processed food: Some people may avoid McDonald's due to the perception that their food is overly processed and contains additives. Environmental impact: The packaging used by McDonald's and the production of their food can have a significant impact on the environment. Labor issues: McDonald's has faced criticism for its treatment of workers, including low wages and poor working conditions. Cultural impact: Some people may criticize McDonald's for promoting a culture of fast food and unhealthy eating habits, particularly among children.

job_title: Crew Member in New York, NY
pros: Flexibility: McDonald's often offers flexible scheduling, which can be helpful for people who need to work around other commitments like school or family responsibilities. Fast-paced work environment: If you enjoy a fast-paced work environment, McDonald's can be a good fit. There's always something to do, and you'll be constantly moving around. Training and development: McDonald's provides training and development opportunities to its employees, including opportunities for advancement. This can be a great way to gain new skills and advance your career. Employee discounts: McDonald's crew members often receive discounts on food and other products, which can be a nice perk. Team environment: McDonald's has a strong team environment, and you'll be working closely with other crew members to serve customers and keep the restaurant running smoothly.
cons: Low pay: McDonald's crew members are typically paid minimum wage or slightly above. The pay is not typically enough to support a family or to live comfortably without additional sources of income. Long hours: McDonald's crew members often work long hours, including nights and weekends. This can be challenging for people who need to balance work with other commitments. High-stress environment: Working at McDonald's can be stressful, especially during busy periods. You'll need to be able to handle high-pressure situations and stay calm under pressure. Physically demanding work: McDonald's crew members are often on their feet for long periods of time and may be required to lift heavy objects. This can be physically demanding work, and it may not be suitable for everyone. Customer service challenges: Working in customer service can be challenging, especially when dealing with difficult or upset customers. Crew members will need to be able to handle these situations with patience and professionalism.
